title: 114_s455
content: The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for the treatment of research credit for certain startup companies. The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" includes provisions for the treatment of the research credit for certain startup companies. Section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow qualified small businesses to elect for the payroll tax credit portion of the credit determined under subsection (a) for the taxable year. The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" allows qualified small businesses to elect for the payroll tax credit portion of the credit determined under subsection (a) for the taxable year. Qualified small businesses are defined as corporations or partnerships meeting specific gross receipts criteria. The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" allows qualified small businesses to elect for the payroll tax credit if their gross receipts are less than $5,000,000 for the taxable year and they did not have gross receipts in any preceding taxable year. This applies to individuals who meet specific criteria as well. The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" allows qualified small businesses to elect for the payroll tax credit by substituting 'person' for 'entity' and considering aggregate gross receipts. The term does not include tax-exempt organizations under section 501. Any election must specify the credit amount and be made by the due date of the taxable year. The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" allows qualified small businesses to elect for the payroll tax credit by filing specific returns under sections 6031, 6037, or for other businesses, the return of tax for the taxable year. Revocation of the election requires consent from the Secretary and is subject to limitations. The "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" allows qualified small businesses to elect for the payroll tax credit by filing specific returns under sections 6031, 6037, or for other businesses, the return of tax for the taxable year. The election is subject to limitations, including a maximum amount of $250,000 and a restriction on making the election for 5 or more preceding taxable years. Special rules apply to partnerships and S corporations making the election. The election under the "Innovators Job Creation Act of 2015" for the payroll tax credit is made at the entity level. All persons or entities treated as a single taxpayer shall be treated as a single taxpayer for this election, with special rules allowing each person to separately make the election. The $250,000 limit is allocated among all persons. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of the subsection, including preventing avoidance of limitations and aggregation rules, minimizing compliance burdens, and recapturing benefits. The IRS will establish regulations for recapturing credits under section 3111(f) in cases of adjustments to the payroll tax credit, requiring amended tax returns when necessary. The taxpayer can claim an amount equal to the payroll tax credit portion for the first calendar quarter after filing the return. The credit is limited to the tax imposed on wages paid to all employees. Any excess credit can be carried over to the next quarter. The credit allowed should not be considered for deductions. The amendments made by this section apply to credits determined for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014. SEC. 3. Research credit allowed against alternative minimum tax. Amends section 38(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow the credit determined under section 41 for eligible small businesses. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2014.
